body: In terms of aggregation across dimensions, The cardinality of metric names seems low enough that the emitter could maintain these averages. Using something like Codahale's histogram.  This gives us a view of something like, p95 of segment scan times / host (for example)
I see various conversation on this PR.  It looks more exploratory.  If there are any things that are still considered blockers on merging this PR, can they be raised explicitly please?

Just FYI, this is not easy in the current way lookups are handled. I'm not sure if @b-slim has considered this case for https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/2291 and other `LookupExtractor` stuff

From what it appears, Druid's metrics were really intended to be consumed by a system like Druid (i.e. one capable of high-cardinality dimensions).  Everything we are discussing are just means to mitigate the fact that Ganglia cannot handle high-cardinality metrics.

Allowing the user to choose which dimensions are included does not solve this problem:  
- If you configure the process to include another dimension, you are not "drilling down" into an existing metric, in Ganglia you are creating a fully new set of timelines/metrics (for each value of the dimension you are now including).  
- Unless your emitter continues to emit at the lower granularity (still not a drill-down, now just an additional metric), you are losing information at the lower granularity, and Ganglia is not going to sum across multiple separate timelines to reconstruct this.

To me, this was reason enough to simply aggregate across all of the dimensions.  This provides a view of your cluster that is amenable to the way Ganglia does things. If this is not sufficient, it would seem that the issue is the metric store, not the metric emitter.

I think we should keep apply(Object), I have a patch WIP that enables long/float dimensions, and it uses that interface:

https://github.com/jon-wei/druid/tree/flex_dims_pt2

If we are to change the ExtractionFn interface, I think it actually makes more sense to collapse all of the apply() functions to apply(Object).

"Stringy" extraction functions like Regex can call .toString() to convert the Object as needed, and other extraction functions like Javascript that are capable of accepting Object should have an interface to do so (JavascriptExtractionFn currently converts Objects to String, but the compiled function is able to accept Object)

@navis see here for the of the discussion why Object was introduced https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/1159. The main reason was in anticipation of having other types of dimensions, including float and long, and so that new types of extraction functions would not need to implement every possible type.
@himanshug according to http://datasketches.github.io/docs/QuantilesAccuracy.html, a tremendous amount of storage is required for reasonable accuracy at scale. How do you solve this problem?

From the table it looks like the error is bounded but the size of the sketch is unbounded. It looks like it grows logarithmically and wouldn't get too crazy at ~trillions of points. But it also seems like the offheap code would have to either tweak the algorithm to make it bounded in size, or start returning errors at some point, as it has to be able to pick a number for max storage.

Is that right @himanshug? if so how were you thinking of handling that?

Have you considered using [Atomix](http://atomix.io/)? It's an Apache 2.0 licensed Java library with an embeddable Raft implementation ([Copycat](http://atomix.io/copycat/)) with support for leader election, cluster membership changes and bi-directional client sessions. Atomix is verified by Jepsen testing for linearizability in failure scenarios (maintained [here](https://github.com/atomix/atomix-jepsen)).

Updated this to rebase on top of changes introduced by:

https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/2085

The PR above changed TimeAndDims to use a dictionary encoded int[] array instead of String[]; this patch uses dictionary encoding for Long/Float values as well (unnecessary).

I plan to change TimeAndDims to use Comparable[] instead of int[] in a later PR, still WIP in my fork:
https://github.com/jon-wei/druid/tree/flex_dims_pt2

Strings will store a dictionary encoding in TimeAndDims as in PR #2085, numerics will store their values directly in TimeAndDims.
@xvrl did you run any tests against this?

@binlijin Please consider [Caffeine](https://github.com/ben-manes/caffeine) if this project is Java 8 based. I'd much rather see projects adopt that then CLHM, if possible. Guava's performance is sadly subpar because I punted on some important optimizations during the port and was then unsuccessful in advocating for them afterwards.

Caffeine supports all of Guava's features, has significantly [higher throughput](https://github.com/ben-manes/caffeine/wiki/Benchmarks#read-100-1), and much [better hit rate](https://github.com/ben-manes/caffeine/wiki/Efficiency#database).

Btw I've been playing with the `implydata/distribution` for some time and I noticed of decreasing indexing performance with growing data sets.

You mention in the [benchmarking-druid](http://druid.io/blog/2014/03/17/benchmarking-druid.html) blog post, that : 

> The resulting Druid segments consist of:
> - a single 589MB segment for the 1GB data set,
> - 161 segments totaling 83.4GB (average segment size of 530MB) for the 100GB data set.
> 
> In our case the indexing service took about 25 minutes per segment for both datasets.

But from what I can see there is a linear decrease in ingestion speed as dataset grows. I tried to increase `Xmx` of relevant components but that doesn't help. The only component that actually does some CPU work and consumes memory is `middleManager`, the others are mostly idling... 

At first I thought that bottleneck is IO because I've been doing the benchmarks on Amazon EBS General Purpose (SSD) volumes, but then I tried physically attached SSD and it was 2x faster but the linear performance decrease was identical ...

Btw my segment size is 1.2GB

@ben-manes Thanks for the info!

I'm filing an issue on the matter. Officially druid only requires java7, but there's no reason an extension would be forbidden from requiring java8.

It is atypical to include an external project's tests and test dependencies, so that shouldn't be an issue.

It sounds like the Guava performance wasn't robust enough to be used as the default. If it was, then Caffeine's Guava adapters would an easy bridge and are most likely Guava v16 compatible.

For Java 7, it does appear that @binlijin was correct and [CLHM](https://github.com/ben-manes/concurrentlinkedhashmap) could be a drop-in replacement for the synchronized map. It introduced the idea of a `Weigher`, then brought over into Guava, to handle the byte sizing issue. It is currently used by Cassandra, et. al, and provides concurrent throughput close to Caffeine. It would be a reasonable stop-gap, with Caffeine preferred in Java 8 due to its superior hit rate.

FYi, there was a brief [discussion](https://groups.google.com/d/msg/druid-development/6I9uhO3ZIeQ/WG-K6JdEEQAJ) on how long we should support java7, which didn't end up in any official position (the discussion is still open).

@gianm there is SegmentsListUsed task action that returns list of used segments. overlord accepts `POST /druid/indexer/v1/action` so user can do it. However, it appears that task action is druid internal communication medium. so, i think, we should create a brand new endpoint then?

@michaelschiff, number one requirement the emit should be non-blocking.
For the dimension/metric discussion, IMHO i think striping out all the dimensions and mixing apples and pear under the same metric does not make sense. Also sending the p95 at a non periodic time won't really make sense as well. I think you can plugin a ganglia emitter on the top of the graphite emitter like that you can take advantage of the queuing implementation and re-writing the dimension via a mapping provided by the user.

@michaelschiff again my main concern is the fact that StatD will do the aggregation of a huge amount of metrics with a very very high cardinality probably onHeap. This can blow the druid process. I think you need a way to filter out the dimensions with high cardinality like query id.
@himanshug I think a new endpoint makes sense if it doesn't already exist (I don't see one) as yeah, the task actions are meant to be internal.
@drcrallen can you please give it a quick look.
@drcrallen can we separate the core stuff from the module stuff ?

@b-slim this is statd's stated purpose. Also 0 aggregation is done in in the emitter, so I am not sure why you are concerned this will "blow away the druid process". As we discussed (at great length) in the Ganglia pull request, this type of filtering does not really solve its intended problem.  

My reasoning regarding the cardinality problem was as such:
- Filtering out any metrics that have any high cardinality dimension (as in the Graphite emitter). This works, but you are throwing away many useful metrics. (e.g. Historical's query/wait/time and query/segment/time are pretty much off limits due to their high cardinality dimension (segment)) -- I see that the json file allows you to specify some number of dimensions to keep.  In the condition that you do not include the full set of dimensions (many of the default cases), how are metrics from different dimension values aggregated? Is Graphite doing this for you? If it is simply plotting them all on the same time-series, you will see some strange things for certain metrics.
- Aggregate across these dimensions in the emitter.  This works in principle (and so long as the # of base metric names stays reasonably small, which it already is, will fit in memory no problem), however you really want to be able to configure the aggregations you are doing, and for what metric prefix you aggregate across.  This seems like its going to be a lot of configuration...
- StatsD is a metric aggregator and forwarder for Graphite and Ganglia.  With a system like this, we can emit metrics at their full granularity from druid, but still get all of the fancy aggregation we want from a system purpose built for this problem
@b-slim Suggest omitting "namespace" from logging since it is really the "lookup name", and not strictly a namespace.
Other than immediately prior comment I'm good here, please squash

@b-slim I'm going to overhaul some of the naming and do the core / extension split once your PR is squashed (and I'll probably rebase onto it, so please rebase your PR on master)

Cool, thanks! :+1:
@dclim for the handoff, you might be missing `druid.selectors.coordinator.serviceName`, that has to match your coordinator `druid.service` for handoff to be detected.
@dclim the whacky errors on not specifying `"type" : "kafka"` are expected and are a jackson thing.

@michaelschiff i think you don't get my message.
i did not dive into the implementation of statd but can you tell me what happen when you call `statsd.gauge(fullName, value.longValue());` million of times ever 1 minute where every call has a unique `fullName`. i am pretty sure statd will try to accumulate and aggregate using an onheap map, does this map has a maximum size, is there eviction ?.
So my point is at the end of this day if you run this code in production, probably you will go out of memory and GC will take over other operations. 
I invite you to test this code in production and you will see what i am talking about.
@b-slim the StatsD client just sends the metric to a StatsD server via a UDP socket. No aggregation takes place within the Druid process.
